docs.snippet: The target date for Facebook's initial public offering continues to change, according to anonymous sources. Last week, TechCrunch reported that company officials had chosen May 17. Today, Kate Kelly of CNBC reported that the social network is more...
docs.abstract: The target date for Facebook's initial public offering continues to change, according to anonymous sources. Last week, TechCrunch reported that company officials had chosen May 17. Today, Kate Kelly of CNBC reported that the social network is more likely to begin its roadshow on May 14, "or even as late as the very end of May," and delay the I.P.O. until early or mid-June.

docs.snippet: A new policy allows some celebrities to use their stage names, even on their personal accounts....
docs.lead_paragraph: A new policy allows some celebrities to use their stage names, even on their personal accounts.
docs.abstract: Facebook introduces new policy allowing some users to go by their established, well-known pseudonyms on their personal Facebook pages; change could be a bid to attract more celebrities.

headline.seo: New Facebook Policy on Made-Up Names Lets Gaga Be Gaga
headline.main: Lady Gaga Now, Even on Facebook
headline.print_headline: Letting Gaga Be Gaga, Facebook Policy Now Allows Made-Up Names

byline.contributor: Brian X. Chen contributed reporting from New York.

docs.snippet: The new strategy for technology companies is to build a device, sell it to consumers and then sell them the content to play on it — and maybe some ads too....
docs.lead_paragraph: The new strategy for technology companies is to build a device, sell it to consumers and then sell them the content to play on it — and maybe some ads too.
docs.abstract: Technology companies are looking to erase the boundaries that separate their devices by concentrating on content and building ecosystems; hiring trends at companies like Apple, Google, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft give clues to a future where hardware and content will merge seamlessly.

headline.seo: Digital Services Seek a Captive Consumer

byline.contributor: Nick Bilton and Nicole Perlroth contributed reporting from San Francisco, and Jenna Wortham from New York.

docs.snippet: "Active users" add up in Facebook's prospectus, but some of those clicks aren't on the Web site....
docs.lead_paragraph: On the first page of Facebook's prospectus for its sale of stock to the public, it pegs the number of its "monthly active users" at a whopping 845 million people. The social networking site arrives at an even more astounding number when it comes to "daily active users": 483 million people.
docs.abstract: "Active users" add up in Facebook's prospectus, but some of those clicks aren't on the Web site.

headline.main: Those Millions on Facebook? Some May Not Actually Visit

docs.snippet: The government's telecommunications minister is meeting Monday with top local officials from Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to ask them to block defamatory or disparaging content before it is published, the India Ink blog reports....
docs.lead_paragraph: As part of the Indian government's continuing efforts to rein in disparaging and defamatory content on the Internet, the telecommunications minister is meeting on Monday with top local officials from Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to ask the companies to prescreen user content from India, the India Ink blog is reporting. The representatives from these companies are expected to tell the minister that the demand is impossible to meet given the volume of content coming from India, and that they cannot be responsible for judging that content. In addition to its efforts to force online services to control what goes up on the Internet, or over wireless connections, the government plans to set up its own unit to monitor information posted on Web sites and social media sites, India Ink reports. Read more »
docs.abstract: The government's telecommunications minister is meeting Monday with top local officials from Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to ask them to block defamatory or disparaging content before it is published, the India Ink blog reports.

headline.main: India Asks Big Web Companies to Screen Content
